author: Peter Fineman
title: Protocol for Social Media Storage
description: Decentralized Social Media must offer users low-friction control of their data, but storage on main chain is costly and controlled centrally

assessments.note:
Its not clear who the client for this product is. 
Is it an existing social media platform? Why would they use this? Is it users? 
How would they use it without a platform on which to use it?
Without a use case to drive take up, how does it help the Cardano Platform?

The proposed idea is an interesting take on the metadata challenge, utilising two levels of NFT's to uphold the Main profile and app specific transactions respectively. Also the incentives for SPO's and dApp users would be key for encouraging adoption. As this proposal is looking at the idea of taking throughput off the main chain, a look at the Hydra scalability solution for certain aspects of the data transaction could be useful more for metric based elements (ie. likes/voting polls etc). The impact could be great as it potentially brings many people into the Cardano ecosystem. Does this approach take into account that a social media platform could potentially run it's own stake pools, which could be a barrier to decentralisation?

While the proposal gives an interesting usecase for metadata and deals with the question of social media data storage, it does not adress the full scope of the issue that is also represented in some of the metrics of the challenge, specifically traceability: While it clearly describes intended mechanisms that are supposed to allow users and SPOs to opt-in or not in the use of their data and to monetize it (which might bring some users that want to monetize their data onto cardano). However regarding traceability, the proposal does not imply giving the data subjects any transparency about how or at least by whom their data is used. Since the proposer has worked a lot in Big Data he should be well aware that this transparency is very important considering recent big data scandals (e.G. Cambridge Analytica, where big data was used to manipulate whole countries politically). I would advice the proposer to adress the aspect of data usage and transparency more detailed in future proposals.

It seems emphasizing a bifurcation of user generated content to an SPO side chain node, opens up the door to some data being securitized in time, (that associated with the blockchain), and other data being left vulnerable (that associated with the SPO Social Media storage), and open to many outside forces associated with the the specific Social Media operations which could vary greatly.
the proposal provides an interesting idea, that if successful could change the way social media is used forever. Where does Digital ID show up in this proposal?

This proposal meets the Metadata Challenge criteria by developing a proof-of-concept standardization of social-media data using a novel combination of on-chain metadata for slowing changing information, coordinated with a side chain for high-frequency data. The proposal acknowledges that moving from a proof-of-concept to widespread adoption would require incentivizing SPOs to host the decentralized side chain, and it properly frames the work as a foundational R&D effort.
The proposer seems to have relevant experience, though is relying on the IOG Team.

The idea is sound and innovative, and the experience shown is solid. The idea itself works well in theory and could be very successful and bring in many users. Details on some KPI's are there, in the form of monthly milestones. But the auditability is hard to define, as is the exact nature of the POC (is it a working app, a dashboard prototype etc). Is this to be solely developed by the proposer with the input from IOHK, or is this going to be a team formed to tackle this proposal. There isn't really a breakdown for budget allocation either.

The proposer obviously is quite experienced in the Big Data topic and has worked for several employers utilizing it. Since the plan is very open-ended it is likely that it will be implemented to some degree, but it is hard to determine the quality to which it will be implemented. The experience of the proposer in blockchain development remains unclear.
The proposer seems to fully understand the need for successful usability and frictionless operations.

While the proposer is well versed in tech, there are some concerns about blockchain experience. This is mitigated with plutus pioneer course and advice from IOHK but it may not be enough in this research based proposal.

Although even the POC effort is ambitious, the proposer appears to have adequate experience for pursuing the project. It would have been helpful if the proposal provided more detail in the roadmap, which is somewhat generic and not directly tied to elements of the technical description of the solution. The project plan would benefit from the use of agile methodology or design thinking in order to continuously engage prospective users as the POC R&D proceeds.

Subsequently moving from the successful POC to widespread adoption would be a high-risk, high-reward effort, but there is a reasonably high likelihood that the POC would result in a sufficiently concrete product to propose next steps.
It is not clear without a usage case that would drive take up how this proposal would help the Cardano ecosystem.

As mentioned in the previous assessment note, there could be more information given on the KPI's and Roadmap and what to expect from the POC although I agree that the function and some KPI's of said POC are indeed outlined, it's more the form that it would take. As well, some kind of budget allocation would help.

The milestones are a bit vague and open-ended and the budget does not have a rationale. More concrete milestones and success criteria would be in order and the propoal should adress some more of the specific criteria of the challenge.

Some clarifications in writing may be helpful for those reviewers who may not be familiar with the discipline-specific language. For instance, when you use an acronym for the first time in a proposal, write the full phrase, and then in parentheses the acronym:
supply path optimisation (SPO) 

Also in this example, avoid definitions like "certain", but instead give an example:

included in certain Cardano main chain transactions initiating the minting of NFTs representing slowly changing entities such as user accounts.
Note: "explain certain" give example of certain...such as...
Does certain mean "user accounts"?

Lastly, it may be best not to compromise user's data persistence on the blockchain for ease of usability... maybe there is a way to educate users about this issue. As some users may opt for this solution out of ease of use, without knowing what they are risking...? 
Referring to thus phrase:

"Furthermore, giving application users full control of the storage and marketability of their metadata may involve expenses and responsibilities that most users would find unpalatable, or even intimidating."
the proposer gave milestones that could be used for gauging progress. However, this alone won't result in realized changes in the number of metadata users.

The proposal's roadmap and solution contains the barely sufficient basic information needed to gauge progress, but it would have benefited from a more quantifiable roadmap and a listing of delivables or artifacts such as a design document, a precise definition of the form of the POC (and its delivery), and the type of testing.

solution: A native-asset storage and access protocol is needed for low-cost, hassle-free mass adoption of social media on Cardano-based networks.
experience: Plutus Pioneer, Social Media Entrepreneur, Software Architect with 25+ yrs global scale analytics and p2p development for EY, KPMG, others
